qas.question: Gray's approach aligns with which approach that Popper himself considered untenable?
A possible rebuttal to Gray's argument appears in Popper's reply to which philosopher?
What did general relativity do that made it tentatively acceptable when it was proposed?

answers.text: explained the empirical refutations of Newton's theory

qas.question: In contrast to Gray, which theory did Popper argue was at least equally consistent with Newton's on the available evidence?

plausible_answers.text: what available evidence these theories were at odds with

qas.question: What does Gray give an indication of?
What did Popper seek to show was logically legitimate?
Whose theory was less well corroborated than Newton's on it's conception?
What was not deemed suitable for tentative acceptance?
Who wrote several decades after Gray's criticism?

context: Gray does not, however, give any indication of <b4_0>what available evidence these theories were at odds with<b4_0/>, and his appeal to "crucial support" illustrates the very <a0_0><b5_0>inductivist<a0_0/> approach<b5_0/> to science that Popper sought to show was logically illegitimate. For, according to Popper, <a3_0><b6_0>Einstein's<b6_0/> theory<a3_0/> was at least equally as well corroborated as Newton's upon its initial conception; they both equally well accounted for all the hitherto available evidence. Moreover, since Einstein also <a2_0>explained the empirical refutations of Newton's theory<a2_0/>, <b7_0>general relativity<b7_0/> was immediately deemed suitable for tentative acceptance on the Popperian account. Indeed, <b8_0>Popper<b8_0/> wrote, several decades before Gray's criticism, in reply to a critical essay by <a1_0>Imre Lakatos<a1_0/>:
